Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Synergistic effects of habitat fragmentation and climate-change driven megafire on biodiversity in a large-scale experiment
Award.AbstractNarration: The natural world is changing in many ways that threaten ecological systems. A big question is whether the threats interact, with some making others much worse than otherwise expected. This project will examine the interaction of two threats, fire and habitat fragmentation (the breaking up of large forests into many small forest fragments), on insects in Australia. Researchers will test how the location of small unburned areas may act as refugia (safe spaces) for beetles, helping them recover in some burned fragments but perhaps not in others. Without nearby refugia, impacts of fire may be especially bad. The project will take advantage of a huge fire in January 2020 that burned through a very big and long-running forest fragmentation experiment. The fire has provided a fleeting opportunity to study how effects of fire may interact with those of habitat fragmentation. Researchers will find and map refugia, relate them to fragment size and habitat, and estimate how many species were wiped out by the fire. Results will allow researchers to figure out how impacts of fire and fragmentation may be related. Also, results will critically inform the management of fragmented forest under increased fire risk. <br/><br/>Relative to their enormous biodiversity and importance in ecosystem function, the impact of severe fire on forest invertebrates is poorly studied. A long, continuous record of beetle biodiversity (over 700 species) before the fire, together with the existing large-scale experimental manipulation of the landscape into habitat fragments, provides a rare opportunity to study possible synergistic effects of fragmentation and fire. The study will provide the first data to evaluate such effects on biodiversity loss and recovery, and the role of small refugia. Additionally, this study of initial conditions and ecosystem trajectory after a severe fire will provide a baseline for long-term study of the drivers of recovery in fragmented forest systems impacted by extreme events that are becoming more common.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study determined the immediate impacts of severe megafire in an experimentally fragmented landscape in southeastern Australia at Wog Wog. The native forest landscape was fragmented 35 years before the 2020 Australian megafires, which burned through the entire experiment. We discovered that the fire left no microrefugia in fragments and just two small microrefugia in continuous forest controls (~2 m2). This is important because the spatial extent of the fires was far greater than ever recorded before, leaving no unimpacted forest nearby, potentially impacting recovery. Fragments burned more intensely than continuous forest, and tree mortality was higher in fragments than in the continuous forest. Tree mortality was highest at fragment cores, most likely because vegetation at fragment cores was dryer leading up to the fire than at fragment edges or in continuous forest. The fire did not impact carabid beetle biodiversity, and carabid beetle biodiversity was not different in fragments and continuous forest after the fire. However, carabid species composition in both fragments and continuous forest after the fire was very different from species composition in any of the previous 35 years, including just after forest fragmentation in 1987. Large, wingless species became rare, and small, winged species became abundant. After the fire, carabid composition in fragments and continuous forest was also different, but this difference was small compared to the difference in composition before and after the fire.
